intro: Juncus bufonius proles minutulus, commonly known as the dwarf bulrush, is a flowering plant native to wetland environments in North America. It is a member of the Juncaceae family and is characterized by its dense, grass-like foliage and small, spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, often forming dense stands in marshes and pond edges. Its flowers are inconspicuous, consisting of three stamens and a single pistil, and it relies on wind pollination. Due to its ability to thrive in aquatic conditions, it plays a vital role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems.
